The n by n identity matrix is a representation of the basis vectors in n-dimensional space that have had no transformation applied to them, and as a result are their own inverse. If you go back to what we learned in geometry, the equations of lines are solvable only if they are not parallel (because parallel lines do not intersect and hence there is no solution).  Say in a two dimensional plane if there are two lines / equations  ax+by+p=0 and cx+dy+q=0, The lines are parallel if their slopes are equal => -a/b = -c/d  which or rearranging gives ad-bc =0, (ad-bc) is the nothing but the formula used to calculate the determinant.  So if determinant is 0, the equation is not solvable (because the lines are parallel).

For those of you wondering why in the first place could we represent the systems of equations as an unknown vector multiplied by a matrix, resulting in a constant known vector. This is because if you do the transformation (dot product) of the unknowns and the matrix, the resulting equations would be the same as the original equations. So the constraints and algebraic structure is preserved. Sal Kahn explaining here: https://www.khanacademy.org/math/precalculus/x9e81a4f98389efdf:matrices/x9e81a4f98389efdf:solving-equations-with-inverse-matrices/v/matrix-equations-systems

I must tell you that I'm very impressed with your treatment of lin-alg in this series of videos. You've packed a solid chunk of a good LA course into a handful of 12-min videos, at a seemingly leisurely pace, with loads of intuition-provoking effects that help make the key concepts stick. It reinforces for me, the reason I subscribed to your channel.

I'd also like to add – around the 1-minute mark in this chapter, where you're talking about the importance of matrices – a suggestion of another very strong reason:
• the way they allow characterizing continuous, non-linear transformations as being locally approximated by linear ones.

This really is something that makes them universally useful. It takes us into the concept of tangent spaces, and, ultimately, tensor calculus, which is the natural language of general relativity and other applications of curved manifolds, by relating nearby tangent spaces. Of course, this more full-blown explanation is well beyond the level of your series here, but I'm confident that you could drop the hints in a most understandable way about this, without going into unnecessary detail...Or maybe in a followup series that delves deeper.

Basically what I was missing is the concept of the "span" of a set of vectors.
Here's my best attempt at an explanation of this concept:

Let there be a set of vectors S.
Now, the span of S is all the points that all the possible linear combinations of the vectors within S can "point to".
Or in other words the span of S is the space that all of the linear combinations of the vectors within S fill.

So if you have two linearly independent vectors, their span is infinite 2D space.
If you have 3 linearly independent vectors, their span is infinite 3D space and, so on.

Hope this makes things clearer. And please correct me if anything is inaccurate.

Why is the determinant of a plane 0, as a result of a 3D matrix squished to a 2D matrix? It has no volume, but neither does a 2D matrix. In the case of a 2D matrix, though, the determinant is (probably) non-zero. So 2D matrices have an area and no volume and mostly non-zero determinants, but 3D matrices need not only area, but also volume to have a non-zero determinant.

By the fourth minute of this video you implicitly explained in just one sentence, why a linear system of equations A*x=b with n equations has exactly one solution if Rank(A)=Rank([A b])=n, multiple solutions if Rank(A)=Rank([A b])<n or no solution if Rank(A)<Rank([A b]). My prof needed two ours of abstract non-sense to proof this without any insight as to why this is.

If Rank(A)=Rank([A b])=n, then all equations/basis vectors are pairwise linearly independent, so every point in space is transformed uniquely. If Rank(A)=Rank([A b])<n then there are at least two equation/basis vector which are linearly dependent, so the points get squished into something without volume (det(A)=0), so a given transformed point has multiple "origins".

For the last case, Rank(A)<Rank([A b]), I couldn't find any geometric interpretation, I just know that there is one equation leading to a contradiction after bringing the Matrix [A b] into row echelon form.

Point of order at 7:02: While it's true that a function can only map a single input to a single output, there isn't technically a problem here; vectors can be seen as ℝ (real numbers) in 1-space and as ℝ×ℝ in 2-space, but- due to a weird quirk of cardinality- there are exactly as many elements in ℝ×ℝ as in ℝ- uncountably many.

This looks wrong to some of you, but it isn't; there are also just as many rational numbers as natural numbers 0, 1, 2, 3...
To see why, you have to think about listing them; being able to give any element of one set a unique name in another. With the positive naturals 1, 2, 3, 4, 5..., you can give it a unique name in the naturals (for EVERY natural) by just subtracting 1 (f n = n-1); 1 becomes 0, 2 becomes 1, 3 becomes 2, etc. So, clearly, there are just as many positive naturals as naturals. There are just as many positive EVEN numbers as there are positive integers in total, and you can show this with f n = 2*n; 2 becomes 1, 4 becomes 2, 6 becomes 3, 8 becomes 4, etc.

There are even just as many integers as naturals; f n = 2*n-1 if n >= 0 else 2*abs(n); so 0 <- 0, 1 <- 1, 2 <- 1, 3 < 2, 4 <- -2, etc.

Now, this is all well and good, but we can EVEN prove that there are just as many rationals as there are naturals. ¿How, you ask? ¡Why, quite simply, actually! We treat a rational number as a fraction n/d, where n is any integer and d is any positive natural. We arrange these into a grid (this is fairly visual, so you'll have to draw it if you don't get it), going to the right as we count n up (using the way of counting integers we gave above) and down as we count d up (just ascending from 1 to infinity).

Now, this grid is infinitely large, of course, so you can't just read left-to-right top-to-bottom or top-to-bottom left-to-right (and you REALLY can't go right-to-left and/or bottom-to-top, because you have to START at infinity). ¿So how do we count, then? ¡Diagonally! Draw diagonal lines going down to the left through the grid, so that every number in column c and row r has c+r the same as every other number on its line. Now, we can simply count in a way that will give EVERY rational a name (in fact, infinitely many with arbitrarily many names) by just going along the diagonals (so looking across the diagonals by where they start at the top, follow them down until you find your number). ¡Success!

Now, the proof for #(ℝ×ℝ) = #ℝ is a bit more complicated, by which I mean I don't know it at all, but I do know it exists. Look it up.

So, therefor, there exists a function mapping vectors in 1-space (from 0 to ℝ, so we can just represent it as ℝ) to vectors in 2-space (from 0 to (ℝ, ℝ), so we can just represent it as ℝ×ℝ). Now, you were obviously restricting us to linear relations, so that makes this entire comment irrelephant. But The More You Know

As a mathematics student,  I find it very interesting to see to what extent you can present properties and concepts in a way that makes them 'very reasonable' (a notion I consider to be right in the middle between intuitive and rigourous and is necessary for good understanding) without any of the obscuring computations. In this video, I found one property missing explanation, that is that surjective maps between spaces of the same finite dimension are also injective. Because this is not explained (I personally wouldn't known how to explain it intuitively) some of your statements are also not obvious, e.g. Why if A is surjective (which as you explained is the case when det(A) /= 0) should A be injective?
